steps.title: There is only one temperament of solder that requires a lower heat (called low-temperature solder).
steps.content: There is only one temperament of solder that requires a lower heat (called low-temperature solder). Jump rings, therefore, do not require a solder that melts at a very high temperature. Cut extra-easy solder into very small chips using tin snips that do not exceed .03 inch (1 mm) squares.

steps.title: Place all cut solder into a designated container and do not confuse or mix it with other varieties of solder.
steps.content: Place all cut solder into a designated container and do not confuse or mix it with other varieties of solder.

steps.title: Open the jump ring with a set of pliers using needle-nose pliers if the ring is small.
steps.content: Open the jump ring with a set of pliers using needle-nose pliers if the ring is small. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Apply flux to both ends of the opened jump rings with a small, fine paintbrush.
steps.content: Apply flux to both ends of the opened jump rings with a small, fine paintbrush. Flux is an agent that assists the solder in flowing into the joint. Flux comes in a variety of forms, but one common form is borax.

steps.title: Close the jump ring with the pliers ensuring that the two ends of the jump ring are flush against one another.
steps.content: Close the jump ring with the pliers ensuring that the two ends of the jump ring are flush against one another. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Place your jump ring on a charcoal block.
steps.content: Place your jump ring on a charcoal block. [3] X Research source Before soldering jump rings, the joint should be touching the block.

steps.title: Pick up one extra-easy solder chip with the tip of the small, fine paintbrush.
steps.content: Pick up one extra-easy solder chip with the tip of the small, fine paintbrush. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Place the solder chip on the joint.
steps.content: Place the solder chip on the joint. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Heat the jump ring as well the charcoal block and do not directly heat the solder.
steps.content: Heat the jump ring as well the charcoal block and do not directly heat the solder. [6] X Research source When you solder metal jump rings, the solder will flow to the hottest place.

steps.title: Watch for the solder to melt.
steps.content: Watch for the solder to melt. The solder will have a liquid appearance at this stage.

steps.title: Watch for the solder to flow.
steps.content: Watch for the solder to flow.

steps.title: This entire process will happen very quickly.
steps.content: This entire process will happen very quickly. Immediately remove the heat.

steps.title: Place the jump ring into a pickle solution.
steps.content: Place the jump ring into a pickle solution. [7] X Research source A pickle is a solution that removes a layer of oxidation on the soldered metal.

steps.title: Wait until you have soldered all jump rings, as they can all be added into the pickle at the same time.
steps.content: Wait until you have soldered all jump rings, as they can all be added into the pickle at the same time.

steps.title: Remove the jump ring(s) from the pickle solution using copper tongs.
steps.content: Remove the jump ring(s) from the pickle solution using copper tongs.

steps.title: Rinse the jump rings with water.
steps.content: Rinse the jump rings with water.

steps.title: Repeat the process on all jump rings requiring soldering.
steps.content: Repeat the process on all jump rings requiring soldering.
